awd_titl_txt: ISN2: Interpretable and Automated Detection of Illicit Online Commercial Enterprises
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will enhance national security, prosperity and health by studying ways to automatically identify illicit commercial enterprises that operate primarily via online advertising.  While many legitimate enterprises use online platforms, such as advertisement services, job recruitment ads, and review boards, illicit business also make use of these services, and it may be difficult to distinguish between them.  Illicit business using these platforms are often associated with human trafficking activity. This project develops methods to analyze large amounts of online data from multiple sources to create an interpretable risk score that facilitates detection of illicit business.  In partnership with the Global Emancipation Network, a data analytics non-profit dedicated to countering human trafficking, the project will fuse data from business-specific operations with data from publicly available licensing documents and court records to better detect suspicious activity and guide resource-constrained interdiction efforts. The results will modernize anti-trafficking efforts to keep pace with the complex strategies used by traffickers.  The award will provide support to educate graduate students to meet the emerging needs of illicit support network research to inform policy.

Using a large existing database of scraped data from the deep and open web, this research will build risk scores for automatically detecting illicit businesses.  Risk scores are linear classification models that only require users to add, subtract and multiply a few small numbers in order to make a prediction, as such, these models are easy to apply and understand.  Information in ads from illicit businesses has distinguishing features, such as data obfuscation, non-random misspellings, high occurrences of out-of-vocabulary and unusual words, and frequent use of Unicode characters, making natural language processing difficult.  The risk score learning problem is formulated as a nonlinear mixed-integer optimization problem.  The analytical framework leverages and extends state-of-the-art techniques from optimization and statistical learning and will produce a scalable branch-and-cut procedure to solve the learning problem over large training sets. It will employ semi-supervised learning methods to use both labeled and unlabeled data to generate better risk scores. The performance evaluation of the risk scores will be informed by real data from legitimate and illicit massage businesses. The research results will be generalizable to different data platforms, and the methods developed in this work is expected to be translatable to detection of human trafficking in other sectors.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Illegal establishments across the United States often pose as massage businesses and force victim workers into a hybrid of sex and labor trafficking, simultaneously harming the legitimate massage industry. This project aimed to facilitate the automated detection of illicit massage businesses (IMBs) by creating interpretable risk scores that link seemingly disparate data points to generate intelligence with high confidence. To this end, experts in operations research collaborated with Global Emancipation Network (GEN), a data analytics and intelligence nonprofit dedicated to countering human trafficking around the world.

 

We utilized findings from primary stakeholder interviews with law enforcement, regulatory bodies, legitimate massage practitioners, and subject-matter experts from nonprofit organizations to identify data sources and potential indicators of IMBs. While IMB review boards like Rubmaps.ch can provide first-hand information to identify IMBs, these sites are likely to be closed by law enforcement. Open websites like Yelp.com provide more accessible and detailed information about a larger set of massage businesses. Data from these sites can be screened for risk factors of trafficking and augmented with other data sources to create robust prediction models.

 

In the first project, we developed a natural language processing approach to detect online customer reviews that indicate a massage business may be engaged in human trafficking. We labeled data sets of Yelp reviews using knowledge of known IMBs. We developed a lexicon of keywords/phrases related to human trafficking and commercial sex acts. We assigned weights to each lexicon term and grouped them into themes. We then built several term-level and theme-level classification models. We also explored multiple methods for expanding the lexicon and learning language patterns in new data. The proposed models can save countless hours in IMB investigations by automatically sorting through large quantities of data to flag potential illicit activity.

 

The second project combined outputs from the lexicon model with several other review-level and business-level metrics to build business-level risk prediction models for IMBs. In addition to the Yelp review and business information, we considered information about the location of the businesses based on census and proximity to places such as truck stops and military bases. We trained interpretable risk prediction models that can determine the risk that a given massage establishment is an IMB. The proposed multi-source data-driven approach can be used by stakeholders at all levels to save time and resources, serve victim-workers, and support well-informed regulatory efforts.

 

In the third project, we explored an active learning approach for obtaining labeled data for building natural language processing (NLP) models. Active learning is a group of strategies for supervised machine learning in which a learning algorithm strategically queries unlabeled data to be labeled by an oracle. We formulated active learning as a decision process and learned an active learning policy through deep reinforcement learning. We assessed the effectiveness of the approach for selecting training data to label for text classification models proposed in the first project. The policy we learn through reinforcement learning achieved a similar or higher F1 score compared to uncertainty sampling. Additionally, the learned policy can perform effectively in a large batch setting, meaning the entire labeling budget can be queried and labeled at once without retraining the classifier. The proposed approach can be useful for efficiently labeling data for other NLP tasks where the proportion of data with the positive class is small and labeling such examples requires significant time and expertise.

 

The intellectual merit of this project pertains to formulating and solving optimization models to develop data-driven and interpretable risk scores with industry-specific indicators to discern IMBs. Combined, the three projects provide a framework for training and maintaining machine learning models for a specific imbalanced classification task that benefits from input from subject matter experts. The results pave the way to modernize combating efforts to keep pace with the complex strategies used by traffickers. IMBs share many features with other types of human trafficking (e.g., using online ads for marketing, luring victims through fraudulent job ads); thus the methods developed in this work can be translated to detect human trafficking in other sectors such as pornography.

 

Data collected for this project has been used in law enforcement investigations and victim service organizations’ efforts in California, Virginia, Georgia, and Texas. We further provided data, analysis, and expertise to external partners which led to new and increased legislation in several states and local jurisdictions. In addition to developing a background in various operations research methods, the graduate and undergraduate students involved in this project experienced extracting, cleaning, and preparing data and working with different types of data. Engineering students were involved in qualitative data collection and analysis. Furthermore, this project was a unique experience for students to be involved in convergence research and work with a team that has extensive domain knowledge in human trafficking and experience in optimization, statistical methods and illicit networks.


Last Modified: 12/22/2023
Modified by: Osman Y Ozaltin
